title: Are folding knives more dangerous than lock blade knives? - Quora

response.answer_text: Are folding knives more dangerous than lock blade knives? This question has existed since the first non-fixed knife was invented. The answer is simple; it is dangerous if you don’t know it’s not a non-locking knife. You approach a slipjoint folder with the same methods and handling you’d used for a fixed-blade knife, yes, it can close on your fingers. However, this almost entirely requires you to be pressing firmly on the point of the knife in a stabby/pokey fashion…which is not how the knife was designed and not what it’s made for. In a slipjoint folding knife there’s a spring that holds the blade in the open position. As long as you’re applying force with the knife blade against that spring as you cut, you’re fine. When the blade opens all the way and stops, apply force with the sharpened side of the blade, not the spine. If you keep this in mind, you’ll have very few problems. Additionally, if the knife is kept sharp…you shouldn’t be needing to apply the kind of force that makes the knife design a factor. The edge should *cut* when it touches something it can cut. If you’re having to get the power of your forearm, elbow, and shoulder into the effort, you’re handling a knife dull enough that it’s presenting a danger to you no matter what design. Or you’re trying to make a cut the knife just can’t make. You’re not cutting through a piece of oak as thick as your wrist in a single slice with a three-inch blade. Rule #1 of Physics that’s not in the books; all physics is relative to Murphy’s Law. If it’d be bad for this knife to slip because you’re applying too much force, it will and at the worst possible moment. How would I define worst? I’ve got a nice scar and a memory of four stitches at the knuckle of my left thumb. The carving project I was doing was going nicely and the design was really coming together. My carving knife was getting a little bit blunt but I had only had a little bit left to do so I didn’t strop it; why make it like a lightsaber now when I always sharpen-to-hair-popping after every session and would be sharpening, carving for fewer than ten minutes, and then sharpening again? Meh, leave it, it’s still plenty sharp enough. Came up to a knot in the wood and, because the blade wouldn’t swish through it, I tried more force. Ah, can’t grip it well, so shift my grip a bit, lever the knife in, and woops. Right into my thumb to the bone. One internal stitch, three external. (Ah, the fun and joys of being old enough to know better, but being too young to care. Glad I grew up some.) Folding knives are designed to be used in ways that compliment their design. Even with a lock-back, I’d be leery to apply a lot of force against the lock because the lock was built in a manner chosen to generate a market-priced knife and could be faulty. Victorinox is one of the most prolific knife companies in the world with their Swiss Army Knife designs that have stood the test of time using the basic slipjoint non-locking design. In the hands of someone sensible to use the knife as designed, it is as safe as anything else in that person’s hands. If you need an ice-pick to do stabby work with high force on the same axis as the blade, get an ice-pick. People often get one concept wrong in relation to knives. “The knife cut me” or “The knife slipped and bit me!” Nope. My carving knife didn’t cut me; I cut me because I was stupid, the knife just helped by allowing my stupidity to become relevant in the moment. When you pick up any knife, look at it, grasp the blade (not on the cutting side) and wiggle it. Which way does it move easiest? Oh, toward the way the blade folds into the handle? Then in the course of use, don’t force the blade to bend/flex/fold that direction. Be smarter than the knife you’re using. It’s plain stupid, only does what you direct it to do. Since it doesn’t have a brain at all, you have to use yours. If, for some reason, that’s not possible…lay the knife down and ask somebody else to use it for you. Additionally, you have a standard lock-back like the Buck 110 folder? It’s got a lock and it’s a good sturdy lock, but it can still fail. Remember what I said about Murphy’s Law? If it’d be a really bad time for that lock to fail, it will fail at that moment. A friend of mine broke a liner-lock knife and it left a beautiful scar along the back of all four of his fingers. You can look at the line of the scars and see how he was holding the knife when the lock failed. Just because this blade can be locked open or closed, it’s a fool’s errand to rely on that too heavily because that lock can fail. The knife doesn’t know the difference between what you want to cut and what you don’t want to cut because it doesn’t have a brain, use yours.

Yes, and decent lockable folding blades are more dangerous than decent fixed blades. I always test the lock on new knives as I have had models with bad locks making them unsafe to use. I have two 91 mm SAKs and one more on its way, they are all without blade locks. I take more care with them than my lockable. That being said. Don't trust the lock without testing it yourself or watch torture test videos on YouTube.

Folding knives come in a lot of varieties and with many different styles of locking or non-locking mechanisms to hold the blade in the open position. The simple old jackknife style uses a flat leaf spring and cam action to hold the blade(s) in position, open and closed. Lock blade folders use liner locks, frame locks, lock back, axis locks, and others, to keep the blade in the open position until it is intentionally released. A jackknife can accidentally close if pressure is put on the back of the blade, possibly catching the fingers under the sharp edge. Locking blades are not supposed to do that. However, neither style will normally have a well defined quillion or hand guard like most fixed blade knives, so the hand can slip onto the blade with forward pressure, stabbing motion.

I consider a folding knife safer than a fixed blade. In its closed position, it’s easy to carry and the blade is tucked away. This prevents any accidental nicks and cuts. A properly stored fixed blade knife takes up a lot more space and can get in the way if not worn effectively. A fixed blade also signals to people that you’re carrying a potentially lethal weapon. Depending on where you are, this may or may not be a disadvantage.

response.answer_text: In some ways, yes. Many folding knives don’t have a lock to keep them open, or the lock is flimsy, so the knife blade could fold back while you’re holding the handle. Many fast-open knives open very easily when they’re closed, so they could open while you’re wearing them. A pouch will help reduce this risk.

response.answer_text: In the right hands… not really. There is always the possibility that you can catch the blade on the underside of something and shut it on your hand… but given that these knives have remained popular for well over 130 years, I wouldn’t say they’re that dangerous. By contrast, the UK has banned the general carry of locking knives, because they are more readily used as stabbing weapons, so one might argue that lock blades are more dangerous in that regard.

response.answer_text: Yes to the person that uses one improperly. The ER is full of people whose fingers have been seriously injured by their own knife blade closing on them

If you are talking about folding knives that don’t lock, they are absolutely more dangerous if used for any sort of real work. A lock is a safety feature that keeps the knife from unexpectedly closing on your fingers and cutting you badly. I insist on locks for all my knives bigger than a keychain Swiss Army knife.

Folding knives are more dangerous than one piece blades, If the folding blade has a lock to hold the blade open it’s better than one that depends upon the force of the cutting to hold the blade open. Keep in mind that lock blades are not as safe as one piece blades - locks can break/disengage allowing the blade to cut you.

response.answer_text: Most folding knives, with the exception of the less common older pocket knives carried by my grandfather, have some sort of locking mechanism and thereby the same. If you are talking about the older style folder they can be more dangerous to the user because the blade can collapse in from a full deployed condition.

response.answer_text: Knives can be dangerous to the user when you don’t respect the knife. By this, I mean that you should understand how it works. How it opens. How it closes. The sharpness of the blade. The limitations of the knife. Once you understand that, you can then use a knife confidently. I still nick myself once in a while, and it’s almost always been because I wasn’t paying attention. Someone said something, or I looked away. A knife is a serious hand tool, just like a wrench or screwdriver. Pay attention, and you’ll be OK.

response.answer_text: A quality, well-built folder will be just as good as a fixed-blade in the extended position. Depends on the lock mechanism used. I prefer “liner locks,” it prevents the knife from folding AT ALL by using a spring section of the liner to block the hinge at a flat spot machined for the purpose. To fold? Just push the liner over with your thumb and fold the blade with your fingers. Do it often enough, and it becomes second nature, or a “muscle memory” (as it is for me, and I finally got my wife to that point as well.) “Liner locks” are typically found in tactical folders, but I prefer those anyhow - they’re (supposed to be, anyhow) rugged, simple, solid blades with good, useful patterns; good-quality materials, easy enough to clean & maintain; and (depending on designer) with a good overall design. I prefer Ernest Emerson, Gil Hibben, Bob Kershaw, & Ken Onion (Emerson’s my favourite. The next three are “no particular order.”)
